title: PhysicalProperties
content:
This file is automatically generated. Please don't edit it manually.
To submit a bug report on the content, see
https://devforum.roblox.com/c/bug-reports/documentation-issues/72

name: PhysicalProperties
type: datatype
summary: |
  Describes properties that affect the physical behavior of a Class.BasePart.
description: |
  The Datatype.PhysicalProperties data type describes several physical
  properties of a Class.BasePart:
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Density|Density,
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Elasticity|Elasticity, and
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Friction|Friction. It is used in the
  similarly-named Class.BasePart.CustomPhysicalProperties property.

  #### Weighting Behavior

  Datatype.PhysicalProperties also provides weightings properties,
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.ElasticityWeight|ElasticityWeight and
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.FrictionWeight|FrictionWeight. When two parts
  interact, the friction and elasticity between them are determined in the same
  way by the following pairwise weighted average function:

  lua
  local function getActualFriction(partA, partB)
  	return (partA.Friction  partA.FrictionWeight + partB.Friction  partB.FrictionWeight) / (partA.FrictionWeight + partB.FrictionWeight)
  end


  Although the formula above refers to the
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Friction|Friction and
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.FrictionWeight|FrictionWeight of two parts,
  A and B, the formula is used in the same manner when determining
  Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Elasticity|Elasticity. Generally, when the
  weight of A is much greater than that of B, the actual value will be
  closer to A. If the weights are similar, the actual value will be close to
  the midpoint between their individual values.
codesamples: []
tags: []
deprecationmessage: ''

        type: Material
        default:
        summary: ''

      Creates a Datatype.PhysicalProperties container with the specified density,

    parameters:
      - name: density
        type: number
        default:
        summary: ''
      - name: friction

      - name: elasticity

        default:

constants: []
properties:
  - name: PhysicalProperties.AcousticAbsorption
    type: number
    summary: |
      A value between 0 and 1 denoting how absorbent the material is to
      Class.AudioEmitter|AudioEmitters.
    description: |
      A value between 0 and 1 denoting how absorbent the material is to
      Class.AudioEmitter|AudioEmitters. When using acoustic simulation,
      surfaces with higher absorption will result in less reverb than surfaces
      with lower absorption.

      Note that this does not affect the degree to which audio transmits
      through surfaces; for that, see
      Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Density|Density.
    default:
    codesamples: []
    tags: []
    deprecationmessage: ''
  - name: PhysicalProperties.Density
    type: number
    summary: |
      The mass per unit volume of the part.
    description: |
      Density is defined as the amount of mass per unit volume. The more dense a
      part is, the more force it takes to accelerate it. Acceptable range is
      0.0001 to 100.0 and values outside this range will be clamped.

      When using acoustic simulation, parts with higher density will muffle
      occluded Class.AudioEmitter|AudioEmitters more.
    default:
    codesamples: []
    tags: []
    deprecationmessage: ''
  - name: PhysicalProperties.Friction
    type: number
    summary: |
      The deceleration of the part when rubbing against another part.
    description: |
      Friction is defined as the force that opposes the relative lateral motion
      of two solid surfaces in contact. The greater the friction on a part, the
      quicker it will decelerate when it rubs against another part with
      friction. Acceptable range is 0.0 to 2.0 and values outside this range
      will be clamped.
    default:
    codesamples: []
    tags: []
    deprecationmessage: ''
  - name: PhysicalProperties.Elasticity
    type: number
    summary: |
      The amount of energy retained when colliding with another part.
    description: |
      Elasticity refers to a part's tendency to retain energy when colliding
      with another part. An Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Elasticity|Elasticity
      of 1 indicates that the part bounces with the same energy it had before a
      collision. Acceptable range is 0.0 to 1.0 and values outside this
      range will be clamped.
    default:
    codesamples: []
    tags: []
    deprecationmessage: ''
  - name: PhysicalProperties.FrictionWeight
    type: number
    summary: |
      The importance of the part's
      Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Friction|Friction property when calculating
      the friction with the colliding part.
    description: |
      The friction weight of two parts rubbing together creates a ratio used to
      calculate the actual friction between the two parts. The higher a part's
      Datatype.PhysicalProperties.FrictionWeight|FrictionWeight, the more its
      Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Friction|Friction is used. Acceptable range
      is 0.0 to 100.0 and values outside this range will be clamped.
    default:
    codesamples: []
    tags: []
    deprecationmessage: ''
  - name: PhysicalProperties.ElasticityWeight
    type: number
    summary: |
      The importance of the part's
      Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Elasticity|Elasticity property when
      calculating the elasticity with the colliding part.
    description: |
      The elasticity weight of two parts colliding creates a ratio used to
      calculate the actual elasticity between the two parts. The higher a part's
      Datatype.PhysicalProperties.ElasticityWeight|ElasticityWeight, the more
      its Datatype.PhysicalProperties.Elasticity|Elasticity is used.
      Acceptable range is 0.0 to 100.0 and values outside this range will be
      clamped.
    default:
    codesamples: []
    tags: []
    deprecationmessage: ''
